user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_alloc_lookahead:
```c
static int lfs_alloc_lookahead(void *p, lfs_block_t block) {
    lfs_t *lfs = (lfs_t*)p;
    lfs_block_t off = ((block - lfs->lookahead.start)
            + lfs->block_count) % lfs->block_count;

    if (off < lfs->lookahead.size) {
        lfs->lookahead.buffer[off / 8] |= 1U << (off % 8);
    }

    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function lfs_alloc_lookahead:
typedef struct lfs {
    lfs_cache_t rcache;
    lfs_cache_t pcache;

    lfs_block_t root[2];
    struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    } *mlist;
    uint32_t seed;

    lfs_gstate_t gstate;
    lfs_gstate_t gdisk;
    lfs_gstate_t gdelta;

    struct lfs_lookahead {
        lfs_block_t start;
        lfs_block_t size;
        lfs_block_t next;
        lfs_block_t ckpoint;
        uint8_t *buffer;
    } lookahead;

    const struct lfs_config *cfg;
    lfs_size_t block_count;
    lfs_size_t name_max;
    lfs_size_t file_max;
    lfs_size_t attr_max;
    lfs_size_t inline_max;

#ifdef LFS_MIGRATE
    struct lfs1 *lfs1;
#endif
} lfs_t
...
typedef uint32_t lfs_block_t
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
static int lfs_alloc_lookahead(void *p, lfs_block_t block) {
    lfs_t *lfs = (lfs_t*)p;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The function writes to members of *lfs (lfs->lookahead.buffer[...] |= ...), so the pointed-to object is intentionally mutable. Rule 8.13 asks for const qualification when a pointer does not need to modify the object. Here the pointer is used for modification, so using a non-const lfs_t * is appropriate. This would only be a violation if the function did not modify the object (in which case the parameter should be const void */const lfs_t *) or if a const-qualified object were cast to this non-const pointer (removing const), which is not shown here.
